After the sterling work of @Salvatore Mercuri , @Madison Crim and @Matthew Jasper we are now much of the way towards a proof that L⊗KAK=ALL\otimes_K\mathbb{A}_K=\mathbb{A}_LL⊗K​AK​=AL​ both algebraically and topologically. There is one mathematically tricky step left, which is L⊗KKv=∏w∣vLwL\otimes_KK_v=\prod_{w|v}L_wL⊗K​Kv​=∏w∣v​Lw​, which Salvatore has recently PRed in the infinite case but which we still need in the finite case. The blueprint has details of a proof which I propose to formalize https://imperialcollegelondon.github.io/FLT/blueprint/Adele_miniproject.html#IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.adicCompletionComapAlgEquiv but I was slightly unhappy with the precision and I tinkered with it in FLT#399, which should hopefully be merged soon.

I think that after the adele refactor is merged, then modulo L⊗KKv=∏wLwL\otimes_KK_v=\prod_wL_wL⊗K​Kv​=∏w​Lw​ what we will need to finish the job is some more API for docs#RestrictedProduct . Let me go through what I think we need to finish the job.

First we need a variant of some work of Maddy. When adeles were a subset of ProdAdicCompletions we needed some API for ProdAdicCompletions and Maddy proved that the construction commuted with L⊗K(∗)L\otimes_K(*)L⊗K​(∗) if L/KL/KL/K is a finite extension of fields. Now we seem to need the analogous result for restricted products (here everything is a commutative ring):

1) Say KiK_iKi​ are a bunch of AAA-algebras, and CiC_iCi​ are sub-AAA-algebras, Let ∏′[Ki;Ci]\prod'[K_i;C_i]∏′[Ki​;Ci​] denote the restricted product of the KiK_iKi​ wrt the CiC_iCi​. If BBB is an AAA-algebra which is finite as an AAA-module, then I claim B⊗A∏′[Ki;Ci]=∏′[B⊗AKi;B⊗ACi].B\otimes_A\prod'[K_i;C_i]=\prod'[B\otimes_AK_i;B\otimes_AC_i].B⊗A​∏′[Ki​;Ci​]=∏′[B⊗A​Ki​;B⊗A​Ci​].

I think this can be broken down into two claims.
1a) Tensor products with finite modules commutes with arbitrary products (e.g. B⊗A∏iCi=∏i(B⊗Ci)B\otimes_A\prod_i C_i=\prod_i (B\otimes C_i)B⊗A​∏i​Ci​=∏i​(B⊗Ci​); Maddy you must have essentially done this?)
1b) Some form of "tensor products commute with filtered colimits" (because the restricted tensor product is just a filtered colimit of things defined in 1a).

Then we need some way of writing down maps between restricted products. I've started on this in the file FLT/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/RestrictedProduct.lean in FLT#399. The point is that the restricted products might be over different types (for example the finite places of KKK and the finite places of LLL) but we want to prove that things are isomorphic.

The kind of results which we need are:

2) Say MvM_vMv​ are types with subsets CvC_vCv​ indexed by v∈Vv\in Vv∈V and say LvL_vLv​ are types with subsets BvB_vBv​ indexed by w∈Ww\in Ww∈W. Say we have a map ccc from WWW to VVV (corestriction, in the application) and for every www we have a map Mf(w)→LwM_{f(w)}\to L_wMf(w)​→Lw​ which takes Cf(w)C_{f(w)}Cf(w)​ into Bw.B_w.Bw​.

Say that for each v∈Vv\in Vv∈V the set c−1(v)c^{-1}(v)c−1(v) is finite, and the map from MvM_vMv​ to ∏w∈c−1(v)Lw\prod_{w\in c^{-1}(v)}L_w∏w∈c−1(v)​Lw​ is an isomorphism, sending CvC_vCv​ to ∏w∈c−1(b)Bw.\prod_{w\in c^{-1}(b)}B_w.∏w∈c−1(b)​Bw​.

Then there's an induced map ∏v′[Mv;Cv]→∏w′[Lw;Bw]\prod'_v[M_v;C_v]\to\prod'_w[L_w;B_w]∏v′​[Mv​;Cv​]→∏w′​[Lw​;Bw​] and the claim is that it's a bijection.

In the application Mv=L⊗KKv=B⊗AKvM_v=L\otimes_KK_v=B\otimes_AK_vMv​=L⊗K​Kv​=B⊗A​Kv​ and Cv=B⊗AAv.C_v=B\otimes_AA_v.Cv​=B⊗A​Av​.
Plus variants when everything is a ring or a BBB-algebra, when it's an isomorphism of rings.
Finally we need that if everything is topological, then the induced map is a homeomorphism.
We will also need the canonical isomorphism L⊗KX=B⊗AXL\otimes_KX=B\otimes_AXL⊗K​X=B⊗A​X if XXX is a KKK-module.
Javier Lopez had claimed L⊗KKv=∏wLwL\otimes_KK_v=\prod_wL_wL⊗K​Kv​=∏w​Lw​ but unfortunately he now has a new job so has little time for mathlib; he's now unclaimed this issue, which is FLT#231 .

I think that we also need the map B⊗AAv→B⊗AKv≅L⊗KKvB \otimes_A A_v \rightarrow B \otimes_A K_v \cong L \otimes_K K_vB⊗A​Av​→B⊗A​Kv​≅L⊗K​Kv​ is injective (i.e., FLT#400 actually proves the thing that it claims to).
I'm happy to take a stab at FLT#231

It might be the case that it's better breaking it up into smaller pieces first. Maybe it's too big to be an issue? But feel free! Make sure you look at the WIP PR by Javier first, there will be some useful stuff there

I feel like I'm missing a trick here. I want to split this argument into two or more pieces. Here's what it looks like to me.

The claim is the following. The set-up: say AAA is a Dedekind domain, KKK is its field of fractions, L/KL/KL/K is a finite separable extension, BBB is the integral closure of AAA in LLL. Then for vvv a nonzero maximal ideal of AAA the claim is that the canonical map Kv→∏w∣vLwK_v\to\prod_{w|v}L_wKv​→∏w∣v​Lw​ induces an isomorphism L⊗KKv=∏w∣vLwL\otimes_KK_v=\prod_{w|v}L_wL⊗K​Kv​=∏w∣v​Lw​.

The proof firstly depends on a choice; choose α∈L\alpha\in Lα∈L such that L=K(α)L=K(\alpha)L=K(α). Using this write L⊗KKv=∏i∈ILiL\otimes_KK_v=\prod_{i\in I}L_iL⊗K​Kv​=∏i∈I​Li​ where III is some auxiliary finite set that depends on α\alphaα and the isomorphism is a map which also depends on α\alphaα. Then say "oh well the LiL_iLi​ match up with the LvL_vLv​ so we're done"

I want to prove the first statement (about the LiL_iLi​) as an independent lemma but I'm a bit confused about what the statement should say. Is there a statement which is independent of α\alphaα and useful? For example one could prove L⊗KKvL\otimes_KK_vL⊗K​Kv​ is a finite sum of fields. But does one need more control over the index set in order to finish the job?

The map {w:w∣v}→spec(L⊗KKv)\{w : w|v\} \rightarrow \mathrm{spec} (L \otimes_K K_v){w:w∣v}→spec(L⊗K​Kv​) given by the maps L⊗KKv→LwL \otimes_K K_v \rightarrow L_wL⊗K​Kv​→Lw​ is bijective. Then show L⊗KvL \otimes K_vL⊗Kv​ is a finite sum of fields?

I agree that the map is a bijection (although this might need "if the valuation vvv on KKK comes from a nonzero maximal ideal of AAA then every nonarchimedean norm on LLL which restricts to vvv on KKK must come from a nonzero maximal ideal of BBB" and I'm not entirely clear on how hard this is). But I'm a bit less clear right now about how that gives "the obvious map L⊗KKv→⊕wLwL\otimes_KK_v\to\oplus_wL_wL⊗K​Kv​→⊕w​Lw​ is a bijection", as opposed to just "there is an isomorphism".

So, letting ϕ:L⊗Kv→∏wLw\phi : L \otimes K_v \rightarrow \prod_w L_wϕ:L⊗Kv​→∏w​Lw​ be the obvious map and πu:∏wLw→Lu\pi_u : \prod_w L_w \rightarrow L_uπu​:∏w​Lw​→Lu​ the projection, I was thinking ker⁡ϕ=⋂wker⁡(πw∘ϕ)=⋂mm=0\ker \phi = \bigcap_w \ker (\pi_w \circ \phi) = \bigcap_{\frak{m}} \frak{m} = 0kerϕ=⋂w​ker(πw​∘ϕ)=⋂m​m=0 to show injectivity and a density approach (using the results from my last PR) to show surjectivity. Maybe CRT could be used instead though.

Yes, it occurred to me also that maybe one just tries to prove directly that the obvious map ϕ\phiϕ is an injection and a surjection. You've got very good at density arguments, perhaps your PR about the integral level extends easily to show that LLL is dense in ∏wLw\prod_w L_w∏w​Lw​?

Can we just take the integral statement and invert πK\pi_KπK​? But I guess showing that (OL⊗OKv)[1/πK]≅L⊗Kv(\mathcal{O}_L\otimes \mathcal{O}_{K_v})[1/\pi_K]\cong L\otimes K_v(OL​⊗OKv​​)[1/πK​]≅L⊗Kv​ could be tricky.
The integral statement assumes the rational one to get injectivity

I think there are two approaches to this.

1) The approach in the blueprint. Here is a concrete statement which is certainly true but I'm unclear about how far we are from it.

We're in the usual AKLB set-up which I outlined above (K field of fractions of Ded domain A, L/K finite separable, B integral closure of A in L), with vvv a nonzero maximal ideal of AAA (i.e. A isn't a field!). Say MMM is a field and an L⊗KKvL\otimes_KK_vL⊗K​Kv​-algebra (e.g. M=LwM=L_wM=Lw​ for some w∣vw|vw∣v). Say MMM is finite-dimensional as a KvK_vKv​-vector space. Then

(i) MMM inherits a norm, extending the norm on KvK_vKv​ (@María Inés de Frutos Fernández do we have this in mathlib yet?)

(ii) The restriction of this norm to LLL is equivalent to the www-adic norm on LLL, for some w∣v.w|v.w∣v.

That is one way to make progress on this L⊗KKvL\otimes_KK_vL⊗K​Kv​ business. Here is a completely different approach, but I don't know how feasible it is: (1) prove that the map L⊗KKv→∏w∣vLwL\otimes_KK_v\to\prod_{w|v}L_wL⊗K​Kv​→∏w∣v​Lw​ is surjective and KvK_vKv​-linear using the ideas which @Matthew Jasper has recently formalized. Then (2) deduce it's an isomorphism by a dimension-count. For this we'll just need [Lw:Kv]=eifi[L_w:K_v]=e_if_i[Lw​:Kv​]=ei​fi​ because we have ∑ieifi=[L:K]\sum_i e_if_i=[L:K]∑i​ei​fi​=[L:K]. Here eie_iei​ and fif_ifi​ are defined globally, so if one were to approach this via a local definition of eee and fff then one would have to relate the local eee and fff to the global one.

I talked about this L⊗KKv=∏wLwL\otimes_KK_v=\prod_wL_wL⊗K​Kv​=∏w​Lw​ issue at LLL and after some discussions I'm really coming around to the dimension count idea. The sorry in FLT#231 says that the canonical map L⊗KKv→∏w∣vLwL\otimes_KK_v\to\prod_{w|v}L_wL⊗K​Kv​→∏w∣v​Lw​ is bijective. I think/hope Matthew's work will show that it's surjective. The dimension count argument to finish is that it's a KvK_vKv​-linear surjection between two finite-dimensional KvK_vKv​-vector spaces of the same dimension so if it's a surjection then it must be a bijection.

The reason I think that we might be closer to this than I'd realised, is that already in the repo we have that if w∣vw|vw∣v then the restriction of www to KKK is vvv scaled by a factor of eee. After the adele refactor bump we have a new sorry saying that the same is true for the restriction of www on LwL_wLw​ to KvK_vKv​, but this is precisely the statement that "local e is global e". The statement that "local f is global f" should just follow from the claim that the residue field of KvK_vKv​ is A/PvA/P_vA/Pv​ which sounds very doable (indeed I suspect that Matthew has introduced all the tools necessary, if it's not there already). So all that is missing is the statement that for a finite extension of nonarch local fields, the degree is efefef, and this sounds very doable.

I'm still confused about the Ostrowski approach. I've had it in my head for years that to prove Ostrowski for number fields (every nonarch valuation comes from a max ideal of the ring of integers) it suffices to prove it for the rationals and then everything is obvious. I'm no longer sure that everything is obvious but maybe what's actually happened is that I've forgotten the proof of Ostrowski and it's got some key technique in it which makes it easy. But one reason I like the local approach is that the dimension being efefef just sounds like an important and useful result in general, and I want to build up the theory of local fields in mathlib. Right now we are still bickering about the definition but I feel like things are converging.
The dim = local efe fef is the global result once you show that Ow/Ov\mathcal{O}_w/\mathcal{O}_vOw​/Ov​ is a finite extension of DVRs (depending on what exactly you mean by "local eee")
